#### Step Response of First-Order Circuits

Another way to characterize linear circuits is by exciting them with step inputs, typically achieved with a square wave of low enough frequency or long enough period, so the circuit settles between edges, making each edge resemble a step input.

Consider a step input \( x_{in}(t) = A_{in} u(t) \), where \( u(t) \), the step-input function, is defined as

\[
u(t) = 
\begin{cases}
0, & t \leq 0 \\
1, & t > 0
\end{cases}
\]

The step function \( u(t) \) has a Laplace transform given by

\[
U(s) = \frac{1}{s} \tag{4.26}
\]

Thus, the Laplace transform of the output of a linear system with transfer function \( H(s) \) and a step input is

\[
X_{out}(s) = A_{in} \frac{H(s)}{s} \tag{4.27}
\]

This is usually straightforward to calculate, especially since any rational \( H(s) \) can be expressed as a sum of first-order terms using residues [James, 2004].

For a first-order low-pass filter with transfer function

\[
H(s) = \frac{A_0}{1 + \frac{s}{\omega_0}} \tag{4.28}
\]

using (4.27), we get

\[
X_{out}(s) = \frac{A_{in}}{s} \frac{A_0}{1 + \frac{s}{\omega_0}} \tag{4.29}
\]

Rewriting (4.29) in terms of its residues yields

\[
X_{out}(s) = A_{in} A_0 \left[\frac{1}{s} - \frac{1}{s + \omega_0}\right] \tag{4.30}
\]

Taking the inverse Laplace transform gives

\[
x_{out}(t) = u(t) A_{in} A_0 \left[1 - e^{-t/\tau}\right] \tag{4.31}
\]

where \( \tau = 1/\omega_0 \).

For a general first-order circuit with transfer function

\[
H(s) = A_0 \left(\frac{1 + \frac{s}{\omega_z}}{1 + \frac{s}{\omega_0}}\right) \tag{4.32}
\]

and subjected to a step input, the output has a Laplace transform of

\[
X_{out}(s) = \frac{A_{in} A_0}{s} \left(\frac{1 + \frac{s}{\omega_z}}{1 + \frac{s}{\omega_0}}\right) \tag{4.33}
\]

Hence, the system's step response is

\[
x_{out}(t) = u(t) A_{in} A_0 \left[1 - \left(1 - \frac{\omega_0}{\omega_z}\right) e^{-t/\tau}\right] \tag{4.34}
\]

where \( \tau = 1/\omega_0 \). The step response for \( t \) slightly greater than 0 is denoted by \( x_{out}(0^+) \) and using (4.34) is found to be

\[
x_{out}(0^+) = A_{in} A_0 \frac{\omega_0}{\omega_z} \tag{4.35}
\]

This can be verified using the Laplace transform property

\[
x_{out}(0^+) = \lim_{s \to \infty} s X_{out}(s) = \lim_{s \to \infty} H(s) A_{in} = A_{in} A_0 \frac{\omega_0}{\omega_z} \tag{4.36}
\]

together with equation (4.33). Similarly, it can be shown that after a long time, when the first-order circuit has settled, its response denoted \( x_{out}(\infty) \) is given by

\[
x_{out}(\infty) = A_{in} A_0 \tag{4.37}
\]

This can be verified using the Laplace transform property

\[
X_{out}(\infty) = \lim_{s \to 0} s X_{out}(s) = \lim_{s \to 0} H(s) A_{in} \tag{4.38}
\]

together with (4.33). Using (4.34), (4.35), and (4.38), one can derive the general equation for the step response of any first-order circuit as

\[
x(t) = x(\infty) - \left[x(\infty) - x(0^+)\right] e^{-t/\tau} \tag{4.39}
\]
